ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:0.2_0: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:0.5_0: 53. The training rule on reviling a group
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.2_0: At that time the nun Caṇḍakāḷī was quarrelsome, argumentative, and creators of legal issues in the Sangha. They were legal issues in the Sangha; there were legal issues in the Sangha; the Monastic Law of legal issues in the Sangha; the nun Caṇḍakāḷī of disputes that had been decided against her.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.3_0: While her legal procedure had compassion for her hand, she objects to her.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.4_0: Soon afterwards when Thullanandā went to a village on some business,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.6_0: took the opportunity to eject Caṇḍakāḷī for not recognizing an offense.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.7_0: When Thullanandā had finished her business, she returned to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.8_0: As she was approaching, Caṇḍakāḷī neither prepared a seat for her, nor set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, or water for washing the feet;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.9_0: and she did not go out to meet her to receive her bowl and robe or to ask whether she wanted water to drink.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.11_0: why she was acting like this.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.12_0: and she did not go out to meet her to receive her bowl and robe or to ask whether she wanted water to drink.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.13_0: She replied, “That’s how it is, Venerable, when you don’t have a protector.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.16_0: that no-one would speak up for me because I am not esteemed by them and I didn’t have a protector, they ejected me for not recognizing an offense.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.18_0: “They are incompetent fools! They don’t understand legal procedures, nor what makes them fail or succeed.” And in a rage she reviled the community.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.19_0: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized Thullanandā,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.20_0: “How could Venerable Thullanandā revile the community in a rage?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.21_0: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā did this?”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.24_0: “... How could the nun Thullanandā do this?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.25_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.26_0: the Buddha said, “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:1.27.1_0: ‘If an enraged nun reviles a community, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.4_0: ... The nun who has been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.8_0: what is meant is the Sangha of nuns.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.10_0: if she reviles them, saying, “They are incompetent fools. They don’t understand legal procedures, nor what makes them fail or succeed,” she commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.11_0: If she reviles several nuns, a single nun, or someone who is not fully ordained, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.13_0: At the fore of the counsel
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.14_0: for the benefit of the teaching
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.17_0: if she is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53:2.18_0: The third rule, the third training rule on fire, is finished.
